name: Raj Patel
backstory: Raj is a software engineer from Hyderabad who came to the US on an H-1B visa sponsored by a mid-size tech company in Austin, Texas. He has been working for three years and his employer recently started the PERM labor certification process for his green card. With the India EB-2 backlog stretching decades, Raj is anxious about his long-term immigration prospects and is exploring whether he qualifies for EB-1 or an NIW to skip the queue.
goals: Obtain permanent residency through employment
Explore EB-1A or NIW as faster alternatives
Maintain valid H-1B status during the process
challenges: Potential layoff risk in tech industry
employmentInfo: Software Engineer at mid-size tech firm in Austin, TX. $125K salary. 3 years tenure.
educationInfo: MS Computer Science from IIT Bombay

name: Maria Elena Gonzalez
backstory: Maria Elena was brought to the United States at age 4 by her parents and has lived in Los Angeles her entire remembered life. She is a DACA recipient who graduated from UCLA and now works as a paralegal at an immigration law firm. With ongoing legal challenges to the DACA program, she is deeply worried about her future status and is exploring all possible pathways to permanent residency, including through her US citizen fiance.
goals: Secure permanent legal status
Explore marriage-based green card pathway
Protect DACA status during transition
challenges: Complex interaction between DACA and marriage-based adjustment
familyInfo: US citizen fiance, parents are undocumented, younger sibling is a US citizen by birth
employmentInfo: Paralegal at immigration law firm in Los Angeles. $58K salary.
educationInfo: BA Political Science from UCLA

name: Wei Zhang
backstory: Wei is a graduate student in electrical engineering at MIT, finishing his PhD in May. He has accepted a job offer from a major semiconductor company in San Jose and needs to transition from F-1 OPT to H-1B. His employer has confirmed they will sponsor his H-1B petition for the upcoming cap season.
goals: Successfully transition from OPT to H-1B
Understand cap-gap protections
Begin employment without status gaps
challenges: Timing of OPT expiration vs H-1B start date
STEM OPT extension as backup plan
employmentInfo: Incoming IC Design Engineer at semiconductor company in San Jose. $155K offer.
educationInfo: PhD Electrical Engineering, MIT (expected May 2026)

name: Amara Okafor
backstory: Amara is a journalist from Lagos who fled Nigeria after receiving death threats for her investigative reporting on government corruption. She entered the US on a B-1 visa and filed an affirmative asylum application within her first year. Her case has been pending for two years with no interview scheduled. She is the sole provider for her two children who are with her in the US.
goals: Obtain asylum approval
Get work authorization while case is pending
Eventually petition for family members left behind
challenges: Supporting children without stable work authorization
familyInfo: Two children (ages 8 and 11) in the US, elderly mother and brother still in Nigeria
employmentInfo: Freelance writer with EAD based on pending asylum application
educationInfo: BA Journalism from University of Lagos

name: Yuki Tanaka
backstory: Yuki is a senior executive at a Japanese automotive company who was transferred to their US headquarters in Detroit as a managerial transferee on an L-1A visa. She has been in the US for two years and her company wants to sponsor her for a green card through the EB-1C multinational manager category. She is also considering whether her contributions to automotive engineering innovation might qualify her for EB-1A.
goals: Obtain EB-1C green card through employer
Evaluate EB-1A as self-petition alternative
Maintain L-1A status during green card process
challenges: EB-1C requires continued employment with same company
employmentInfo: VP of Engineering at Japanese auto manufacturer US HQ in Detroit. $210K salary.
educationInfo: MS Mechanical Engineering from Tokyo Institute of Technology

name: Carlos Rivera
backstory: Carlos has been living in Houston for 8 years under Temporary Protected Status granted to Salvadoran nationals. He works in construction and has built a stable life with his US citizen wife and two US citizen children. With TPS facing periodic re-designation uncertainty, Carlos wants to explore whether he can adjust status through his marriage to a US citizen, complicated by the fact that he entered the US without inspection.
goals: Adjust to permanent resident status through marriage
Maintain TPS status as safety net
Understand implications of entry without inspection
familyInfo: US citizen wife, two US citizen children (ages 3 and 5)
employmentInfo: Construction foreman in Houston. $52K salary.

name: Priya Sharma
backstory: Priya moved to the US as a dependent on her husband's H-1B visa. She holds an MBA from a top Indian business school and previously worked in management consulting. After her husband's I-140 was approved, she obtained an H-4 EAD and now works at a startup in Seattle. She is concerned about the recurring legal challenges to the H-4 EAD program and wants to explore getting her own independent work visa.
goals: Maintain H-4 EAD work authorization
Explore own H-1B sponsorship as backup
Understand impact of husband's green card process on her status
challenges: H-4 EAD program under legal challenge
Dependent on husband's H-1B and I-140 status
Own H-1B would require lottery selection
familyInfo: Married to H-1B holder with approved I-140
employmentInfo: Product Manager at startup in Seattle. $115K salary.
educationInfo: MBA from Indian School of Business

name: Jean-Pierre Duval
backstory: Jean-Pierre has lived in Miami for 15 years under TPS originally granted after the 2010 Haiti earthquake. He owns a small restaurant and employs 12 people. Despite deep roots in the US, his TPS has been subject to repeated legal challenges and temporary extensions. He needs to understand his options if TPS is terminated, including any available waivers or alternative relief.
goals: Find long-term immigration solution beyond TPS
Explore cancellation of removal if TPS ends
Protect his business and employees
challenges: No underlying immigration status if TPS ends
Building cancellation of removal case requires 10 years presence
familyInfo: Three US citizen children (ages 10, 13, 16), ex-wife is a US citizen
employmentInfo: Owner of Haitian restaurant in Miami. 12 employees. $180K annual revenue.

name: Soo-Jin Kim
backstory: Soo-Jin invested $200,000 to open a boutique Korean skincare store in New York City on an E-2 treaty investor visa. The business has been profitable for two years and she wants to renew her E-2 status. She is also curious about whether she might eventually qualify for an EB-5 immigrant investor visa if she scales her business.
goals: Renew E-2 visa successfully
Understand E-2 to EB-5 pathway
Explore hiring E-2 essential employees
challenges: E-2 is non-immigrant with no direct path to green card
EB-5 minimum investment threshold is much higher
Business must remain operational for E-2 renewal
employmentInfo: Owner of Korean skincare boutique in NYC. $350K annual revenue. 5 employees.
educationInfo: BA Business Administration from Yonsei University

name: Ahmed Hassan
backstory: Ahmed is a medical researcher on a J-1 exchange visitor visa at Johns Hopkins, subject to the two-year home residency requirement. His research in oncology has produced significant publications and his department wants to sponsor him for an H-1B. He needs to understand the J-1 waiver process and whether he can obtain a waiver based on a no-objection statement from Egypt or through an interested government agency.
goals: Obtain J-1 two-year requirement waiver
Transition to H-1B for continued research
Eventually pursue EB-1B outstanding researcher green card
challenges: Coordinating with Egyptian government for no-objection letter
employmentInfo: Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Johns Hopkins. $62K stipend.
educationInfo: MD from Cairo University, PhD Oncology from Johns Hopkins

name: Fatima Al-Rashidi
backstory: Fatima worked as a translator for the US military in Iraq for five years and received a Special Immigrant Visa. She arrived in the US six months ago and is settling in Virginia with her husband and young daughter. She needs guidance on adjusting to permanent resident status, accessing refugee resettlement benefits, and eventually applying for citizenship.
goals: Complete adjustment of status to permanent resident
Access SIV resettlement benefits
Understand timeline to naturalization
challenges: Understanding which benefits SIV holders can access
familyInfo: Husband (SIV derivative) and 3-year-old daughter
employmentInfo: Currently job-seeking, formerly US military translator in Iraq
educationInfo: BA English Literature from University of Baghdad

name: Isabella Torres
backstory: Isabella is a domestic violence survivor who cooperated with law enforcement in the prosecution of her abuser. She filed a U visa petition three years ago and is still waiting on the massive backlog. She has a bona fide determination and work authorization but lives in fear that her abuser, who was deported, may return. She also wants to understand how her pending U visa affects her children's immigration status.
goals: Obtain U visa approval
Secure status for her three children as U derivatives
Explore VAWA self-petition as parallel path
challenges: Children aging out of derivative status
familyInfo: Three children ages 9, 14, and 17 (aging-out risk for eldest)
employmentInfo: Home health aide with U visa-based EAD. $32K salary.

name: Oluwaseun Adeyemi
backstory: Oluwaseun is a data scientist who has been working in the US on an H-1B visa for four years. He has published several papers on using AI for public health in developing countries and believes his work qualifies for a National Interest Waiver. He is self-petitioning without employer sponsorship to gain independence from his current employer.
goals: File and win EB-2 NIW petition
Maintain H-1B while NIW is pending
Gain employer independence through self-petition
challenges: Documenting national interest of his research
employmentInfo: Senior Data Scientist at healthcare AI company in Boston. $145K salary.
educationInfo: PhD Data Science from Georgia Tech

name: Mei Lin Chen
backstory: Mei Lin has been a lawful permanent resident for six years after obtaining her green card through her US citizen daughter. She lives in San Francisco and runs a small accounting practice. She wants to apply for naturalization but is worried about the English language test and civics exam. She also made a trip to China that lasted 7 months and is concerned it might affect her continuous residence requirement.
goals: Pass naturalization interview and exams
Understand impact of 7-month absence on continuous residence
Obtain US citizenship
challenges: Extended absence may disrupt continuous residence
familyInfo: US citizen daughter who petitioned for her, two grandchildren
employmentInfo: Owner of small accounting practice in San Francisco. $95K annual revenue.
educationInfo: BA Accounting from Fudan University, Shanghai

name: Pavel Novak
backstory: Pavel is an award-winning film director who came to the US on an O-1B visa for individuals with extraordinary ability in the arts. He has directed several acclaimed independent films and won awards at Sundance and SXSW. His agent is helping him navigate a green card through EB-1A extraordinary ability. He needs to understand documentation requirements and maintain his O-1B while the green card is processing.
goals: File EB-1A petition based on film achievements
Maintain O-1B status during processing
Understand premium processing options
employmentInfo: Independent film director. Variable income averaging $180K/year.
educationInfo: MFA Film from FAMU, Prague

name: Ana Beatriz Silva
backstory: Ana Beatriz entered the US on a B-2 tourist visa to visit family in Newark, New Jersey. She overstayed her authorized period by 14 months and is now out of status. She recently married a US citizen and wants to adjust her status to permanent resident. Her overstay complicates matters significantly, and she is worried about triggering the 3/10 year bars if she leaves the country.
goals: Adjust status to permanent resident through marriage
Avoid triggering unlawful presence bars
Understand whether she can adjust despite overstay
challenges: Accumulated over 1 year of unlawful presence
Must prove bona fide marriage amid overstay
familyInfo: US citizen husband married 3 months ago, no children
employmentInfo: Unemployed, no work authorization
educationInfo: BA Marketing from PUC-Rio, Brazil

name: Mohammad Rezaei
currentStatus: Asylum granted, applying for green card
backstory: Mohammad is an LGBTQ+ activist from Tehran who was granted asylum in the US three years ago after demonstrating a well-founded fear of persecution based on his sexual orientation. He now lives in Chicago and works for a human rights NGO. Having held asylee status for over one year, he is eligible to apply for adjustment of status to permanent resident and wants to understand the process.
goals: Adjust from asylee to permanent resident status
Understand asylee adjustment timeline
Eventually petition for his partner still in Iran
challenges: Documenting one year of asylee status
Partner in Iran faces persecution risk
familyInfo: Partner in Iran awaiting ability to join him in the US
employmentInfo: Program Coordinator at human rights NGO in Chicago. $55K salary.
educationInfo: MA Human Rights from University of Tehran

name: Grace Mutua
backstory: Grace won the Diversity Visa lottery and recently arrived in the US with her husband and teenage son. She is a nurse by training and wants to get her Kenyan nursing credentials recognized in the US so she can work. She needs to understand the steps after arrival as a new permanent resident, including getting a Social Security number, understanding conditional vs unconditional residency, and beginning her career.
goals: Get nursing credentials evaluated and recognized
Obtain Social Security number and begin working
Understand permanent resident rights and responsibilities
familyInfo: Husband (DV derivative) and 16-year-old son
employmentInfo: Registered Nurse in Kenya, seeking US credential evaluation
educationInfo: BSN Nursing from University of Nairobi

name: Diego Morales
backstory: Diego crossed the US border as an unaccompanied minor at age 16 and was placed in removal proceedings. He was released to a family member in Maryland and a juvenile court found that he had been abused and neglected by his parents in Guatemala. His pro bono attorney is helping him file for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status. He is now 22 and worried about aging out of eligibility.
goals: Obtain Special Immigrant Juvenile Status before aging out
Get removal proceedings terminated or obtain relief
Adjust status to permanent resident through SIJS
challenges: Aging out risk at age 21 (may have TVPRA protections)
Gathering evidence of abuse and neglect from Guatemala
familyInfo: Living with uncle in Maryland, parents in Guatemala (abusive household)
employmentInfo: Part-time warehouse worker with EAD. $22K/year.
educationInfo: GED obtained in Maryland

name: Svetlana Petrova
backstory: Svetlana is a successful businesswoman from Moscow who invested $800,000 in an EB-5 regional center project in Florida. Her I-526E petition has been pending for 18 months. She is currently in the US on a B-1 visa and needs to understand whether she can remain, when she might receive conditional residency, and what happens if the regional center project encounters financial difficulties.
goals: Obtain conditional permanent residency through EB-5
Understand regional center project risks
Plan for I-829 petition to remove conditions
challenges: Regional center project financial viability concerns
employmentInfo: Former real estate developer in Moscow. Retired with investment portfolio.
educationInfo: MBA from Moscow State University

name: Anh Nguyen
backstory: Anh became a US citizen 10 years ago after immigrating through family sponsorship. She now wants to petition for her younger brother who is still in Vietnam using the F4 family preference category. She understands the wait time is extremely long but wants to start the process. She needs guidance on filing the I-130 and understanding the visa bulletin priority dates.
goals: File I-130 petition for sibling in F4 category
Understand visa bulletin and priority dates
Plan for the long wait time
challenges: F4 category has 20+ year backlog for Vietnam
Brother must maintain eligibility throughout wait
familyInfo: US citizen, petitioning for brother in Vietnam. Own family: husband (US citizen) and two adult children.
employmentInfo: Nail salon owner in Houston. $120K annual revenue.

name: Kofi Mensah
backstory: Kofi graduated with a Master's in Data Analytics from NYU and is currently on STEM OPT extension working at a financial services firm in Manhattan. His employer wants to sponsor him for an H-1B but he was not selected in the last lottery. He needs to understand his options if he is not selected again, including potentially pursuing a second master's degree or finding an H-1B cap-exempt employer.
goals: Get selected in H-1B lottery
Explore cap-exempt employer options
Understand backup plans if lottery fails again
challenges: STEM OPT will expire in 18 months
employmentInfo: Data Analyst at financial services firm in NYC. $95K salary. E-Verified employer.
educationInfo: MS Data Analytics from NYU

name: Rosa Delgado
backstory: Rosa has lived in the US for 14 years without legal status, working as a housekeeper. She was placed in removal proceedings after a traffic stop. She has three US citizen children and no criminal record. Her immigration attorney believes she may qualify for cancellation of removal for non-permanent residents, which requires showing 10 years of continuous physical presence and that removal would cause exceptional and extremely unusual hardship to her US citizen children.
goals: Win cancellation of removal in immigration court
Demonstrate exceptional hardship to US citizen children
Obtain legal status and work authorization
challenges: Must prove 10 years continuous physical presence
Exceptional hardship is a very high legal standard
familyInfo: Three US citizen children ages 8, 12, and 15. Children have medical and educational needs.
employmentInfo: Housekeeper, paid in cash. Approximate income $28K/year.

name: Dmitri Volkov
backstory: Dmitri fled Ukraine after the Russian invasion and was admitted to the US through the Uniting for Ukraine parole program with his wife and elderly mother. He was a mechanical engineer in Kyiv and is trying to rebuild his career in the US. His parole is temporary and he needs to understand options for longer-term status, including TPS for Ukrainians and potentially asylum.
goals: Apply for TPS for Ukrainian nationals
Explore asylum as parallel pathway
Get engineering credentials recognized for employment
challenges: Parole status is temporary with no direct path to residency
familyInfo: Wife and elderly mother (both U4U parolees)
employmentInfo: Formerly Mechanical Engineer in Kyiv. Currently seeking engineering work with parole-based EAD.
educationInfo: MS Mechanical Engineering from National Technical University of Ukraine

name: Camille Bernard
backstory: Camille recently arrived in the US on a K-1 fiance visa after her American partner filed the I-129F petition. She has 90 days to marry her fiance and file for adjustment of status. She is a pastry chef who wants to open her own bakery eventually. She needs to understand the adjustment process, work authorization timing, and travel restrictions during the process.
goals: Marry fiance within 90-day window
File I-485 adjustment of status promptly
Obtain EAD and advance parole for work and travel
challenges: Cannot leave US before adjustment filing
familyInfo: US citizen fiance in Portland, Oregon
employmentInfo: Pastry chef, not yet authorized to work in the US
educationInfo: Diplome from Le Cordon Bleu, Paris

name: Rajesh Krishnamurthy
backstory: Rajesh has been in the US for 18 years on an H-1B visa. His employer filed his green card petition under EB-2 India, but with the extreme backlog, he has been waiting 12 years with no end in sight. His attorney suggested downgrading to EB-3 where dates are moving slightly faster, while keeping the EB-2 petition active. He is now maintaining two petitions and is confused about priority date portability and the implications of job changes.
goals: Understand EB-2 vs EB-3 backlog movement
Maintain priority date across petitions
Explore job portability under AC21
challenges: Job change risks under AC21 portability
familyInfo: Wife on H-4 (with EAD), two children born in the US
employmentInfo: Senior IT Manager at consulting firm in New Jersey. $165K salary. 18 years in the US.
educationInfo: MS Computer Science from University of Pune

name: Lucia Fernandez
backstory: Lucia fled Venezuela's political and economic crisis and received TPS in the US. She married a US citizen who became physically and emotionally abusive. After leaving the relationship, she filed a VAWA self-petition as a battered spouse. Her case is complicated by the intersection of TPS, VAWA, and her desire to adjust status without her abuser's knowledge or cooperation.
goals: Win VAWA self-petition approval
Adjust status independently from abuser
Protect herself and children from retaliation
challenges: Intersection of TPS and VAWA is legally complex
Abuser must not be notified of VAWA petition
familyInfo: Two children ages 4 and 6 (US citizens through abusive spouse)
employmentInfo: House cleaner with TPS-based EAD. $30K/year.

name: Tariq Al-Farsi
backstory: Tariq is an undergraduate student at the University of Michigan studying computer science. He is funded by an Omani government scholarship that requires him to return home after graduation. However, he received an exciting job offer from a tech company and wants to understand whether he can accept it, what obligations his scholarship imposes, and whether OPT is possible given his government funding.
goals: Understand scholarship return obligations vs OPT eligibility
Explore options for post-graduation employment
Determine if J-1 restrictions apply to his scholarship
challenges: Government scholarship may impose return requirement
May technically be on J-1 not F-1 depending on funding source
Balancing career opportunity with contractual obligations
employmentInfo: Student, part-time research assistant. Job offer: $110K from tech company.
educationInfo: BS Computer Science, University of Michigan (expected May 2026)

name: Esperanza Cruz
currentStatus: Nurse on EB-3 green card process
backstory: Esperanza is a registered nurse from Manila who was recruited by a hospital chain in Texas. Her employer filed an EB-3 petition for her and she has been waiting for her priority date to become current. She is currently working on an H-1B visa. The Philippines EB-3 backlog is shorter than India's but still significant. She wants to bring her parents to the US once she gets her green card.
goals: Track priority date and visa bulletin for EB-3 Philippines
Understand when she can file I-485
Plan family petition for parents after green card
challenges: Future F2B petition for parents will have its own backlog
familyInfo: Single, parents and siblings in the Philippines
employmentInfo: Registered Nurse at hospital in Dallas, TX. $78K salary.
educationInfo: BSN from University of Santo Tomas, Manila

name: James Okonkwo
backstory: James is a political activist from Nigeria who was arrested and detained by CBP after arriving at a US port of entry and requesting asylum. He passed his credible fear interview and was placed in removal proceedings where he can pursue a defensive asylum claim. He is currently detained at an immigration detention center in Louisiana and needs help understanding the bond process, his rights in detention, and how to prepare his asylum case from inside detention.
goals: Obtain bond to be released from detention
Win defensive asylum case in immigration court
Understand rights while detained
challenges: Must prove persecution claim while detained
familyInfo: Wife and children still in Nigeria
employmentInfo: Political organizer in Nigeria, currently detained
educationInfo: BA Political Science from University of Ibadan
